climbs.name: Who'da Thought?
climbs.fa: Eric Rasmussen, Rob Segger and Matt Shubert, April 1988

content.description:
Delicate climbing along right-slanting seams gains a thin dogleg which is followed partway to open face climbing higher which eventually merges with

Dinky Doinks

.
content.location:
Starts in right-slanting seams between

Dinky Doinks

and

Cole Lewis

.

content.description: This is the thin crack to the left of the wider crack Dinkey Doinks. This is on the east/northeast face. A beautiful crack that eases off after the crux at the bottom.
content.protection: Takes small to medium nuts and cams. large pro for the anchor.

climbs.name: Spontaneous Human Combustion
climbs.fa: Dave Evans and Jim Angione, October 1988

content.description: Clip bolt 1 and aim to stand on a small knob to clip bolt 2, which is an old Leeper. Marginal friction leads to bolt 3, which seems newer. Aim for a flat black hold, which enables a clip into another old Leeper (1/4 incher). A righthand sidepull flake leads, with ones head exploding, to the roof and a cam. Finish either left (large cam) or right. Rope drag can be a problem.
content.protection: 4 bolts and cams for the upper crack. A full length fall onto bolt 4 might shear it off. Until the upper 3 bolts are replced this route is an R/X IMHO.
content.location: The right edge of Tiny Tots

content.description: This is a fairly nice crack climb.
content.location: This route is on the north end of the rock, around the corner to the right from the other routes. It goes up a corner and over a small overhang.

content.description: Probably the best route on the wall.  This is the most obvious crack line up the east face, the third from the left. Climb up on locks and jams though solid moves to the top. Good pro, good rack, good fun at a moderate grade.  Not much winter sun on this though.

Of the 60+ routes I did on J-tree in my last trip there, this was the third-least enjoyable...Buford's House of Liver was worse, and Junk Yard God sucks bald dog nuts.

Anyway, the climb itself has some less-than nice rock and gear, and the belay up top is a pain & blinded from the nice views you get from the top of other routes. This line starts up a crack on the N. End of the E Face (no sun in the winter) and continues up to an area past some crumbling rock and right onto the NE end of the rock. This would be a mentally and physically harder lead for most moderate climbers than Dinkey Doinks (5.8) would be.
content.protection: A standard light rack up to 4"

content.description: The far left crack when facing the east/northeast face.
content.protection: Small to medium gear for the route; medium to large gear for the anchor.
